This Company's system of submarine telegraph

South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with the Orient Railways Express Service for VIENNA, BERLIN, PARIS & LONDON.
The S. S. Osmanieh will resume her express sailings on May 8.

PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.–The fast steamers Prince Abbas and Assouan leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina, continuing in alternate weeks to Larnaca (Cyprus).

SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.–The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express serice to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.–Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden
For further information refer to Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez, or to THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIKA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: THE SITUATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: Sir Auckland Colvin, who has filled in Egypt the important offices of Comptroller-General and Financial Adviser to the Khedive, writes in the April number of the "Nineteenth Century and After" on "Egypt To-day." The main purpose of the article is to refute the contention set forward by Mr. Edward Dicey in his recent book "The Egypt of the Future," namely, that the British authorities are working on wrong lines. To Mr. Dicey's suggestion that "the old laws, usages, customs, and habits should remain as they were before the Protectorate existed," Sir Auckland Colvin replies : "What were these laws, usages, customs, and habits? The old usage was the corvee, 'the old custom was the kurbash, the old laws were, in Lord Dufferin's words, 'a mockery,' 'misery and confusion'; the old habits were corruption, bribery, and speculation. The prisons were foul dens. 'No words could convey the impression of the hopeless misery of the mass of the prisoners,' wrote a Commission in. 1882, which had been appointed to look into them, 'who live for months like wild beasts, without change of clothing and half starved, ignorant of the fate of their families, and bewailing their own.' Are these the laws, usages, customs, and habits which Mr. Dicey would wish to have restored ? Does he seriously contend that it should be the role of the British authorities in Egypt merely to maintain order and the defence of Egypt, while the governing classes of the country administer it ? Are the British to keep the ring, always facing scrupulously outwards, while the kurbash and the corvee have full play within ? " "The absolute authority which Lord Cromer is said to wield," writes Sir A. Colvin, "is made a grave reproach to him in 'The Future of Egypt.' There can be no manner of doubt that Lord Cromer's influence in Egypt is on the whole paramount In the first place—and this is of itself enough—he represents his Majesty's Government* which holds Egypt in the hollow of its hand He has been for thirty years intimately connected, in one or other office, with the administration of the country, and his knowledge of its affairs is probably far greater than that of any other living man. He has brought Egypt from the depths of distress and insolvency into the sunshine of the most unheard-of prosperity. He enjoys the prestige of unbroken success achieved among extraordinary difficulties. By personal force of character, by patience and prudence, by tenacity, by fearless and unswerving devotion to the interests committed to him, he has gained universal respect and very general confidence. Such a man stands too high and too conspicuous a figure to escape the slings and arrows of misrepresentation. But to describe him as an 'absolute autocrat' is mere misuse of language. . . . Not to he weary of well-doing is the first and best lesson to be learned by the European reformer in the East He has put his hand to the plough, and he cannot withdraw it Least of all can he succumb to the atmosphere of the Orient and, whether from complaisance or from lack of purpose or of courage, fall into a system of laiseer aller. That would be to turn his back on the very influences which have brought him there; to be a renegade to the civilisation of which he is a pioneer, and of which the battle has been entrusted to his hands."

div.head: The Principessa Maria...
div.p: The Rumanian mail steamer Principessa Maria, which went on the rocks off Tenedos towards the end of January, has been reftoated after long and extremely laborious efforts on the part of the local salvage firm io which the work was entrusted.

div.head: Fire in Attarin Quarter.
div.p: A small outbreak of fire occurred in a house in the Attarin quarter of Alexandria about half past eleven last night. The brigade arrived quickly on the scene and the fire was extinguished before any damage of note was done, but a Berberin was very badly burnt.and..ne hope is entertained of his recovery. -

div.head: Saint Menas City.
div.p: The Rev. Carl Marie Kaufmann has published a second volume dealing with his researches at the city of Saint Menas in Mariout This work, which is entitlerl, "Zweiter Bericht über die Ausgrabung der Menas-Heiligtümer in der Mareotiswiister" gives an accoont of the progress of the excavations from June to November last year. It is published by Diemer, Cairo, and costs 7 mark 50. This account of the discoveries during last summer is most interesting and is admirably illastrated.

div.head: Egyptian Play in London.
div.p: The new Egyptian play, "The Judgement of Pharaoh", by Mr. A C. Calmour, will probably be ready for production at the Scala Theatre, London, during the last week of this month. Rehearsals are now in full progress, the leading parts being entrusted to Messrs. Brandon Thomas, James Fernandez, Edmund Gurney, and Misses Cecil Cromwell and Norah Lancaster. Miss Cromwell is a very beautiful actress, who comes from the Adelphi, and Miss, Norah Lancaster, a danghter of Mrs. Lancaster Wallis, brings an excellent repntation from the provinces. Mr. Bruce-Smith and Mr. Helmsley are jointly responsible for the ! scenery. The banqueting hall in the palace of Egyptian Prince Pharus, and the Temple of Osiris, will be magnificent specimens of scenic art. The date of the play is that of the time! when the children of Israel were a flourishing agricultural nation, under the rule of patriarehs, and should be fixed somewhere between 1000 and 600 B..

div.head: A New Industrial City.
div.p: The name of Koppel has become well-known in Egypt through the Cairo and Alexandria agencies of the firm Arthur Koppel Ltd. and many of our readers will be interested to learn that a new town to be known as Koppel is nearly completed in Pensylvania. This new town is destined to be one of great industrial importance, since the intent and desire of the entire population will be to produce portable and industrial railway equipment of the most improved designs and highest efficiency. The organization at the head of this gigantic undertaking is the well-known Arthur Koppel Company, of New York whose thirty years of continuous service in the production of railway equipment has brought its products into use in every part of the civilized world. Its location is an admirable one, being but 35 miles from Pittsburg, Pa., and having excellent shipping facilities by rail and water. In the heart of the great iron and steel belt, this new industrial town will harbor one of the largest and most complete plants for supplying one of the greatest accessories of modern industry.

div.head: British Recreation Club.
div.p: A concert was held on Saturday evening at the British Recreation Club, at which there were present Lady Cromer, General, Mrs., and Miss Bullock, Crookshank Pasha and Mrs. Crookshank, Mr. and Lady Valda Machell, Dr. and Mrs. Milton, Capt. and Mrs. Blakeney, Dr, and Mrs. Madden, Mr. W. M. Hayes, Ms. and Mrs. Rowlatt. Mr. 8. H. Trimen, Mr. and Mrs. Nolan, Madame Amster, Captain Macmurdow, Lieut. Col. S. O. F. Donegan R. A. M. C., Mrs. Wilding, Captain Tucker, and very many others. Unfortunately Mrs. Elliot Smith, whose name was on the programme, was unwell and could not appear. At the end of the concert Crookshank Pasha proposed a vote of thanks to Lady Valda Machell for having got up the concert and to all the ladies and gentlemen who had so kindly entertained i 11s. He also thanked Lady Cromer for being present and expressed his deep regret that it would be her last visit to the Club and he hoped that Lord Cromer's health would be i greatly benefited by his rest and change or climate ; he referred to Lady Cromer's kindness in presenting the prizes every Christmas and said how much she would be missed. Bouquets were presented to the lady performers and a very excellent concert was brought to a close by the singing of the National Anthem.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S RESIGNATION. ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPAL MEETING. THE NATIVE MEMBERS' BOYCOTT.
div.p: Yesterday a meeting of the members of the Alexandria Municipality was held in order to send an official and collective expression of their regret at the resignation of Lord Cromer. All the European members of the Municipality were present except Mr. E. W. P. Foster, C.M.G., and Baron Alfred de Menasce, who could not attend owing to their absence from Alexandria. A very noteworthy fact, which was much commented on by the members who were present, and which has caused great * in terest throughout the city, as showing the attitude of the natives at the present time, was that the only natives present were the two official members (membres de droit) of the Alexandria Municipality, Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria, the Presi dent of the Municipality, and Mohamed Bey Mahfonz, Chief of the Parquet in the Native Tribunal at Alexandria. All

regrets une forme concrete et durable, je vous propose donc de confier au marbre et au bronze d'un monument a elever sur one de nos places le soin de perpetoer le souvenir des services rendus a l'Egypte en general, a la ville d'Alexandrie en particulier par Lord Cromer. Quant a nous qui avons ete temoins de sa vie publique, nous garderons lorequ'il aura gague l'Angleterre la memoire fiddle de tout ce qu'il a realise de bien d'utile et de juste dans ce pays. After Schiess Pasha had finisched speaking Maitre Padoa Bey made the following speach.
Je m'associe a l'hommage eloquent que Notre Vice-President vient de rendre au

Comte de Cromer Quel que puisse etre l'ave-nir, son nom restera dans l'histoire de l'Egypte, entoute de respect et de reconnaissance- Dans l'impulsion qu'il a donnee au pays,il a apporte une intelligence, une lucidite et une hauteur de vues, une nettete de, decision dont le re-sultat a ete une veritable transformation du pays. Notre municipalite nee sous ses auspices, s'est toujours ressentie de son action bienfaisante. Ma pensle se reporte bien souvent vers l'epoque oil, dans one sphere modeste, j'avais l'honneur de suivre aupres du major Baring et de son eminent collegue M. de Blignieres, les premiers pas de la regeneration de l'Egypte. l'amenite et la droiture de celui qui devait etre Lord Cromer lui avaient deja concilie les sympathies de tous. Il etait difficile de l'approcher sans ressentir un veritable atta-chement pour sa personne. Aujourd'hui qu'il nous quitte, apres avoir realise comme der-nidre ceuvre cet accord qui permet a tous Une voie parallele, il m'est bien permis de dire que ce sentiment s'est toujours conserve intact a travers la. diversity des evene-ments. Je m'associe a la proposition de notre President et je propose que la Municipality ouvre, a son budget extraordinaire, le credit necessaire pour la realisation du projet qu'il vous a presente, ou pour la fondation d'une ceuvre (Futility generale

After this speech a committee was chosen, a member from each nationality as follows : Mr. Kingham, English, Yehia Pasha, Egyptian, Mr. Feuderl, Austrian, Dr. Valensin, Italian, Mr. Rothaker, German, Mr. Escoffier, French, Mr. Salvago, Greek, and as chairman, Schiess Pasha, Swiss

It was then discussed what was the best way of acting upon Dr. Schiess Pasha's resolution, which was carried unanimously, and it was finally decided to erect a monument, though what form the monument shall take is as yet undecided.
A telegram was then sent to Lord Cromer on behalf of the Municipal Commission, expressing their sincere regret at his Lordship's resignation and the reason which had compelled him to so decide. |

Lord Cromer responded telegraphically to Moustafa Pacha Ibadi, President of the Commission, as follows:— Je prie Votre Excellence d'accepter et de communiqner aux membres de la Municipalite l'expression de mon appréciation la plus sincere de l'hommage insigne qu'ils me rendent, et dont je suis infiniment touchy et tres flatty.
Cromer.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HORSE SHOW
div.p: The Annual Horse Show was held at the Sporting Club grounds on Saturday. The show may have been up to the standard of former years, but taking it as a whole from an unbiassed spectator's point of view, the least one can say is, that it was far from a huge success. The attendance during the early part of the day was meagre, although things brightened up a little after lunch, but even then at their beat the numbers were not what one would have anticipated. This was a pity as there was sufficient material in the number of entries, and the goodly array of prizes, including some handsome cups, to have ensured a most successful and enjoyable meeting. But interest in the various events seemed to flag, on account perhaps of the monotony of the judging, the long waits, and what we cannot but call the lax organisation in allowing the non-competitors in particular classes to drive and ride all over the course while others were being judged, so that one hardly knew which event was taking place. The programme, too, might have been arranged differently, in order to have finished earlier. As it was, darkness had almost set in ere the last event was concluded: in fact it was at first thought that two of the classes would have to be postponed. The result was that very few people remained to the distribution of prizes which had to be presented in the dark until someone came to the rescue with a small lamp.

The most popular classes of the afternoon were the children's hacks,and the jumping competition ; one little fellow in the former shewing considerable skill in managing his rather i fractious steed, and another caused some amusement by absolutely refusing to be' driven or coaxed past the judges. In the I latter, the jumping competition, the after-' noon was marred by what appeared at first a serious accident to Mr. D. S. Alderson, one of the competitors. None of the horses took to the jumps kindly, only one jumping at ' all cleanly and with style. Mr. Alderson had, however negotiated the first two hurdles, but J at the third, the hedge, his mount plunged into the side rails, threw its rider, who was apparently unable to release his hold of the reins, and appeared to be badly trampled. The doctor was immediately in attendance bat we were glad to learn upon making enquiries that his injuries were not all all serious, although he had of course received a severe shaking from which we trust he will speedily recover. The band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers played during the day and lunch was catered for by the management of the New Victoria Hotel, Ramleh.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive arrived at Koubbeh Palace from Alexandria on Saturday evening, and yesterday morning he spent at Abdeen Palace,
receiving Lord Cromer in audience. In the afternoon he granted audiences to Prince Ibrahim Halim, Count Gabriel de Zogheb, Sir William Garstin, and Mr. Milter.

div.head: BAD WEATHER AT SUEZ.
div.p: INDIAN MAIL BOAT DELAYED.
( From our own Correspondent. )
Suez, Sunday.
Since early this morning a Southerly gate has been raging at Suez, and communications with steamers lying at anchor in the roads in almost impossible
The steamers, owing to the wind and hazy

weather, are unable to enter the Canal, and the majority of those in the Canal this side of Suez, have been moored since this morning Up to the time of writing (5 p.m.) no signs of abatement of the gate are visible.
| Among the detained steamers at Suez is the P. a nd O. mail steamer from India.

div.head: M. DE FERAUDY
div.p: "Paraltre" is not a profoundly interesting piece, it is rather detached, meaningless, devoid of any great central feature. The thread of the story is the love of JeanRaidzell for Christiane Marges, but with this are various other casual side-issues—Germaine Laconderies's story of blackmail and collusion, and Eugene Raidzell's financial gasconnades, not to mention Paul Marges' electoral compaigns: After all, perhaps, that isfairly life-like one does not-find connected stories in four or five acts in real life, but one does expect them on the stage, so M. Maurice Downay's play is either a failure or a piece of premature realism. M. de Feraudy as the worthy baron and general adviser had little enough to do, but his fine command of detail again told : every word, look, aud gesture was effective. Mile Van Daren was admirable, but she is hardly a sympathetic actress of personality : She incites analysis rather than fascination. MmeBressau as Christiane was exceeding-ly good, and Mme Marie Laure surpassed herself in her scene with Madame be Gringois (Mime Dunville). The men all had their good moments but were inclined to exaggerate ; that, with de Feraudy on the stage, was fatal, the contrast of method and result being too obvious. I must here rectify and apologise for an error in "Les affaires sont les affaires." I mentioned M. Severin as Xavier Lechat,whereas that part was actually taken by M, Deniere. M. Severin (in "Paraltre") had plenty to do, but he did it well, but the has a slight tendency to the conventional. To conclude, the acting was distinctly better than the 'piece itself. Why should the author have tacked on that absurd explanatory last act epilogue rather-with the pauvre petit bonhomme ? It is unfair to his actors and unworthy of himself.

div.head: "LE JUIF POLONAIS."
div.p: This is an old-fashioned, sensational drama: it is practically "The Bells" and savours of a past generation. M. de Feraudy, as Mathis, was perhaps best in the second act, and the third act is pure Surrey-side ranting. He was impressive enough, but one would argue that the lines of the part were far too clearly marked out to evoke any real unconventional acting. M Rodrigue, as the "President" was unnecessarily noisy, and the hypnotist likewise abandoned too soon his air of mystery and command. He was the Old Bailey lawyer, shouting at the witness. The notable feature of this scene was the staging, the darkened room, the shrouded: lamp the disposal of the whole was telling, and presented most thoroughly the effect of dream and darkness, mystery and terror. Mme Maine Faure excellent as Catherine, perhaps better than in any of the parts she has hitherto played. It is not a great part, but her presentment of it was fault- less. The rest were quite good, but a piece so steeped in conventional melodrama is hardly calculated to call forth any phenomenal originality. The test of their abilities will arise in the more modern pieces which we may hope to see presented.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: An amateur gala performance, such as that of last Saturday in aid of the Jewish Hospital, is necessarily one where criticism would be misplaced. 1t is a case for the journalist rather than the critic, and, as such, is liable to carry (laudatory journalese to its utmost confines. To begin with there was a prologue in verse daintilly ecited by Mme Antoniadis. Then came a little two-scene pantomime entitled "Le Collier de Saphirs" by Catulle Mendes with music by Gabriel Pierne. This afforded scope for Mr. Rodocanachi to display his capacities as a tragi comic pierrot and it is not too much to say that he succeeded in bringing out the salient features of his compartively long role. Mrs. Downng made a very fasimating Pier rette with a semi-dignified grace that became her admirably. Mr. C. Tamvaco appeared to considerable advantage as a pedlar and Maste Benachi as a little black page After an interval of over 35 minutes the orchestra, under Sig. de Marzi, played Grieg's Danae d'Anitra from the Peer Gynt suite ; but we regret to say it was drowned by the incessant talking of the crowded audience. The curtain then rose on Bayer's "Puppengee," in which the "whole strength of the company appeared." We have no hesitation in saying it proved a really splendid performance and went without a hitch from start to finish. The dresses were at once gorgeous and tasteful.

We have tried hard to give adequate and impartial praise to all who took part in it but, long before our task was accomplishied, our stock of adjectives ran short; so we must rely on its intepreters and their spectators to supply the necessary approbation to suit her (or his) convenience and judgment.
We feel bound to observe, after making all allowances, that to commence an entertainment at fully 3/4 hour after the advertised time is quite inexcusable.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman liner; Assiout sailed from Alexandria on Saturday evening for Liverpool with a general cargo, including 1616 bales of cotton.
The S.S. Carib Prince with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on the 12th inst and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 28th April.
The S.S. Imperial Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left London on the 13th inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about 30th April.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Saba Pasha, the Postmaster General, having completed thirty-five years' service, has asked the Minister of Finance to allow him to retire. His Excellency's request has
been granted.
Boutros Pasha Ghali returned to Cairo yesterday from Alexandria.
Sir Malcolm MeIlwraith, Judicial Adviser who came down to Alexandria two days ago, returned yesterday to the Capital.
Mrs. Moffett Potts, wife of Bimbashi Thomas Moffett Potts, of the Egyptian Coast Guards Administration, gave birth to a son, at The Rise, Whitchurch, Oxon, on the 4th, inst

Boutros Bey Hasnim has been confirmed in the appointment of Mamour of Public Security at the Alexandria gouvernorat in the place of Mohamed Heddaya Bey, who was recently promoted the post of Sub-Mudir of the Sharkieh province.
Sir James and Miss Blyth have arrived in London from Egypt.

Among those who left for Europe by the Austrian Lloyd S.S. Habsburg on Saturday afternoon were Sir Frederick Adair, Count Szapary, Count and Countess Karoly, Countess Palffy, Baron and Baroness de Knoop, Count and Countess Chorinsky, and Chevalier de Puscarin, formerly Austro-Hungarian Consul at Alexandria and now transfered to Milan.

div.head: A MAP OF MARIOUT.
div.p: There is no map with any pretensions to topographical exactitude of the country between Alexandria and the Tripoli border. and there seems to be little chance of the Survey Department undertaking any work in this part of Egypt for some time to come, as the survey of the inhabited part of the country for cadastral purposes will take years before it is complete, while the geological survey will be confined for some time to the Eastern desert owing to its mineralical possibilities. We are glad therefore to hear that Mr. Ewald Falls, the German archeologist at the city of Saint Menas, is preparing at his own initiative a map of Mariout and Marmarica. The map, which is to be as accurate as possible from a cartographical point of view, will. especially deal with the ancient sites of this interesting and still comparatively unknown tract It should be of use to future explorers. Some of the old sities in Mariout are mentioned in the second report of the excavations at the city of Saint Menas, a notice of which work appears in another column of to-day's issue. An ancient Christian basilica at Sidi Tadem and the "Matyrion" of Petrus the Martyr near Tapo-siris Magna have recently been discovered by Mr. Falls.

div.head: SUDAN SURVEYS.
div.p: Last week the Royal Geographical Society granted the award of the Cuthbert Peek Grant to Major C.W. Gwynn, R E. who in 1899-1900 carried out an important survey expedition from Roseires, on the Blue Nile, southwards to the Sobat or Baro River, and again in 1900-1 took a leading part in an expedition yielding important geographical and cartographical results along the proposed Sudan-Abyssinian frontier.

This recognition of the excellent survey work that is being done in the Sudan is well deserved. The work of the Sudan aucrey is proceeding rapidly. Lost year a addition was made to the number of printed maps on the scale of 1 to 1,000,000, and a number of incomplete sheets on the scale of 1 to .250,000 have been issued for temporary use.

The cadastral survey of the Dongola Province has been completed 400 maps have been compiled, covering an areaa of 80,000 acres. The cadastral survey is now proceeding in the Berber Province. 411 maps, representing an area of 41,000 acres, have been completed ; also 60,000 acres have been mapped in the Khartoum Province. Some preliminary measures have also been taken which will materially facilitate the survey of Ghezireh, or the country lying between the Blue and White Niles.

div.head: FRANCE AND EGYPTIAN COTTON.
div.p: Le " Temps " draws attention to the fact that while French banks and mercantile houses, are eager to speculate in cotton in Egypt, which is under British protection, they will not stir to promote the growing of cotton in the French Colonies. For centuries cotton has been grown in Indo-China, and the conditions are very similar to those obtaining in Egypt, but huge stretches of land are left uncultivated, for Chinese labour, which is so plentiful in Siam and Malaya, cannot be got, although the French do their best to procure it. The reason given is the want of money, but the factdiv remains that Consul-General Hardouin, who is well-known to the Chinese, has failed to obtain the labour required. how the French capitalists seem to fight shy of their own colonies, and will not invest money in them, and we may, therefore, take it as a great compliment to our administra-tion that they will do in Egypt what they refuse to do in Indo-China.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ENTERPRISE
div.p: AND DEVELOPMENT COMPANY.

Nous apprenons que \'Egyptian Enterprise and Development est en pourparlers pour la vente d'on de Bes domaines sis au village de Dakahla (Dakahüeh), d'une superficie de 2,300 feddans environ. Ce domn:ne a ociVé à la .Compagnie près de vL.d& 90,000 et a été amélioré aveo grand soin.

On se rappelle que par suite de la oession des terrains de Demerd&che-Eoobbeh à la nouvelle Sooiété formée à Anvers et dénommés la Koubbeh Garden City Cy, l'E iterprise and Development a dé, à lé^sé, un bénéfice de L.E. 55,000.

div.head: CHARBIEH LAND COMPANY.
div.p: La Conseil d'Administration vient de publier son rapport sot le 1er exeroice qui oomprend une période de 19 mois.

Le Domaine de la Sooiété oonsiste en 8711 feddans dout 700 feddans sont en plein rapport. L'exploitation de ces derniers font seuls l'objet dn oompte Profits et Pertes présenté par la S.crété. Les dépenses nécessitées par la mise en valeur du restant du Domaine ainsi qu'une partie des frais généraux et d'inspeotion sont ajoutés au prix initial des terrains qui atteint ainsi L.E. 42.3-0 par feddan, ooût sensiblement supérieur au prix d'aohat. De très importants travaux ont, toutefois, été acoom plis et pièj de 6000 feddans sont aujourd'hui pourvus des travaux d'irrigation et de drainage nécessaires.
Le oompte Profits et Pertes ainsi dressé pré sente nécessairement des bé;;éfi 3oa qui en l'es- pèoe s'élèvent à L.E. 6.859,839.
Ce résultat permet de porter en déduotien do
ooût des terrains une a^pe .de L E. 2 114,172.
Le restant est répafS^'insi : £ 84 pour divers ammortissements, LE. 185 à la réserve, L.E. 1,000 aa Conseil d'Administration et L.E. 4 0 à l'Alministrateur-Délégué

div.head:
LORD CROMER'S RESIGNATION.
EUROPEAN TRIBUTES. FRENCH AND GERMAN APPRECIATIONS.

div.p: The French and German press make most sympathetic comments on the retiral of Lord Cromer and express confidence in the policy of this successor (Reuter)

The newspapers speak with great admiration of Lord Cromer. The "Koelnische Zeitung" says that everything the English have done in Egypt for the last quarter of a century has been valuable, solid, and .durable. The "Lokal Anzeiger" says that Lord Cromer is one of tfie most important statesmen of the British Empire who has guided with great skill and success the important interests of England in Egypt. The "Vossisehe Zeitung" states that Lord Cromer during his 24 years of service in Egypt has not only forwarded British influence in the land of the Pharaohs but has at. the same time considerably developed the education of the country and its économie and moral condition. England is under the greatest obligation to this statesman, and Sir E. Grey did not exaggerate in the House of Commons when he said that Lord Cromer's resignation was the greatest loss which the British Government could sustain. The "Norddeutsehe Allgemeine Zeitung" says that Sir E. Grey's speech on I/ord Cromer's retirai shows in what high esteem this illustrious statesman is held in his own coun tty. There is no doubt that Lord Cromer has acquired the greatest, merit in establishing England's position in Egypt ; but in foreign countries, and especially in Germany, it is recognised that his work in Egypt from the point of view of civilization has left durable witnesses of a fertile work in the domains of legislation and administration. Lord Cromer has taken the leading part in the financial amelioration of the country, in the improvement of communications and in ( the irrigation of the Nile valley which has j extraordinarily developed the fertility of the ! country as it appears from his last annual J report. I Lord Cromer has falcen in hand important ' reforms the carrying out of which this great j statesman has decided to leave to his successor. (Reuter)

The ''Times" says that while Lord Cromer's j loss is a national blow, the interlude in the , House of Commons yesterday shows that a Î complete agreement exists between both part ies ; to pursue the work linked with his name. The I appointment of Sir Eldon Gorst ensures the j continuity of his policy. .(Reuter)

div.head:
U.S. PEACE CONGRESS.
Mr. CARNEGIE AS PRESIDENT.

div.p: The Arbitration and Peace Congress of the United States opens here toslay under the presidency of Mr. Carnegie. The object of the Congress is to voice, in view of the Hague Conference, Aiqerican sentiments in favour of general arbitration treaties and a world Congress, with gradually increasing powers lead ing up to a gradual disarmament. Earl Grey, Mr. Bryce, Mr. Stead, and numerous other foreign prominent men will attend and speak- on the different aspects of the peace movement. President Roosevelt will probably also lie present.(Renter)
The Central-American war is ended. The Honduran President, M. Bonilla, has surrendered to the Nicaraguans. (Heater)

div.head:
PERSIAN MINISTER OF INTERIOR
CRITICISED FOR INACTIVITY.

div.p: The Minister of the Interior who has been severely criticised by Parliament for inactivity has resigned. (Reuter)

div.head:
FRANCE AND GERMANY.
POSSIBILITIES OF AGREEMENT.

div.p: The "Neue Freie Presse" learns that diplo- matic circles in Berlin, in view of the develop-ment of relations between France and Ger-many considers an agreement possible by which Germany will make concessions on the Morocco question. (Havas)

div.head:
ENGLAND AND ITALY
KINGS TO MEET AT GAETA.

div.p: King Edward and King Victor Emmanuel will meet on 18th April at Gaeta. They will be acconqianied by Queen Alexandra and Queen Helena. The British and Italian squadrons will escort the respective royal yachts. (Reuter)

div.head:
RUSSIAN WORKMEN'S DELEGATE.
CONDEMNED PRESIDENT ESCAPES.

div.p: M Krustuleff, president of the Council of Workmen's Delegates, who was condemned to life long oxile last year, has escaped abroad from Sjberia. (Reuter)

div.head:
MUTINY AT RIGA
TROOPS CALLED OUT.

div.p: A mutiny has occurred at Riga prison : troops were summond : tkoy 'fired killing or wounding 19 persons : 9 soldiers have been wounded. (Ren\uter)

div.head:
NOBLES AND THE DUMA
PETITION FOR DISSOLUTION.

div.p: A Congress of nobles intend to petition the Tsar to dissolve the Duma. (Reuter)

div.head:
STANDARD OIL COMPANY.
CONVICTION AND APPEAL.

div.p: The- Standard Oil Company has l>een ; convicted by the United States District Court of receiving rebates. No penalty has been im posed pending appeal to a higher court. (R )

div.head:
THE PARIS BAKERS' STRIKE.
NOT BECOME GENERAL

div.p: The strike of linkers partiaily begun on Thursday has not liecome general, only 750 out. of 5,000 have gone on strike. Gendarmes are guarding the bakeries and the streets are patrolled. (Reuter)
The jury in the Thaw case have disagreed and have been discharged. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE IENA DISASTER,
CAUSED BY POWDER.

div.p: The senatorial commission of enquiry have reported the explosion on the Jena to lie due to the so-called B powder. (Reuter)
The King and Queen have arrived and were heartily cheered. They will stay for several days. (Reuter)
The Duke and Duchess of Connaught bave arrived They will stay for a few days in Paris. (Renter)
The cruiser Invincible has been launched at Elswick, Great secrecy as to the vessel's details is observed. (Reuter)
The destroyers Ferret and Osprey collided in the Channel. Both have been damaged, the Osprey seriously. (Renter)
The band of the 82nd English regiment has arrived to take part in a charity fete. Many cordial addresses have been exchanged. (Havas)
In consequence of the revelations of Mgr. Montagini papers, M. Pichon has bring M Lemarchand before the counsel of directors. (Havas)
Sir Walter Nugent, Nationalist, has been returned unopposed for South Westmeath. (Reuter)
General Botha landed at Southampton. The Mayor and Corporation drove in state to the docks, and presented him with an address. (R.)

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
div.p: MORE QUESTIONS.
RADICAL PERTINACITY.
The following answers to questions on Egyptian subjects have of late been given by j Sir Edward Grey :

Dr. Rutherford —To ask the Secretary of. State for Foreign Affairs, whether, notwithstanding that the war in the Sudan was concluded in 1899, several of the Dervish emirs or commanders are still imprisoned at Damietta, in Egypt, under severe disciplinary regulations; whether he will state the grounds for their their continued incarceration; and whether, having regard to the present peaceful condition of the Sudan, he will recommehd the authorities In Egypt to grant their immediate liberation.
I have no information, but will make en-quiries.
MINISTRY OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION.

Dr. Rutherford,— To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, what had been the proportion of British subjects to Natives employed as teachers and inspectors in Egyptian Government schools above the grade of kuttabs (elementary) during the last five years.
The whole subject is dealt with in Lord Cromer's Report for last year, which will shortly be presented to Parliament.
TEACHERS' PENSIONS.

Dr. Rutherford,— To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, what are the salaries and pensions payable to Native and European teachers respectively in Egyptian Government Schools above the grade of kuttab (elementary school); when were they fixed ; within what period, if at all, and by how much, have they been augmented. I will make enquiries, and see whether the information desired by the Hon. Member can be obtained.
PELLAGRA IN EGYPT.

Mr. John Robertson,—To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether, in view of the prevalence in Egypt of the disease pellagra, resulting from the ingestion of bad maize, he will advise the Egyptian Government to take some such measures of prevention as have been prescribed by the Italian law against pellagra of the 21st July 1902.
I have no information on the subject, but will make enquiries.
CONSCRIPTION IN EGYPT.

Mr. John Robertson —To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether, in view of the repeated official avowal that the present military conscription in Egypt, with exemption by purchase from ballotage, is a bad one, which cannot be defended on prin-ciple, as stated in Lord Cromer's Reports for 1904, p. 43, and 1905, p 68 ; and in view of the fact that numbers of poor Egyptians annually sell their small possessions in order to purchase exemption, thus leaving the Army to be constitted by unwilling recruits, he will advise the Egyption Government to take into consideration the expediency of establishing a system of paid military service such as exists in Britain.

Lord Cromer, in the passages of his Reports cited by the Hon. Member, gives the reasons which render the abolition of the present system difficult and inexpedient. The condi-tions of thé country would make it impossible to introduce with success a military system such as exists in the United Kingdom ; but the subject, as may be seen from Lord Cromer's Report, continues to engage attention. Mr. Robertson asked whether this declaration —as to the impossibility of a system such as that of Britain—is to be taken as final, and whether the Foreign Secretary exercioes no control. Sir E. Grey answered by repeating the final clause of the above answer.
LESSONS IN ENGLISH

Mr. John Robertson,—To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether his attention has been drawn to the fact that in the Government primary schools of Egypt object lessons and geography are taught in English only ; that in the Government secondary schools history, geography, arithmetic, geometry, algebra and science are taught in English or in. French only ; and that in the technical schools and professional colleges (with the exception of the school of law, where French is still partly used), all instruction is imparted in English only, and frequently by teachers who are quite unfamiliar with the vernacular ; and whether, seeing that the employment of a foreign tongue as a medium of tuition increases the difficulty of acquiring accurate knowledge of any subject, and is regarded both by the parents of pupils and the pupils themselves as an unnecessary hardship, he will advise the Egyptian Government to employ the vernacular henceforth as the sole medium of tuition.

The language question constitutes a very difficult problem for the Egyptian Educational Department, chiefly owing to the dearth of teachers competent to give the necessary instruction in Arabic, and the absence of scientific text books in that language.

In the circumstances, the Egyptian Govern-ment are frequently placed in the dilemma of either giving instruction in a European language, or being content with an inferior standard of teaching. And, in general, they have preferred the former alternative. They are, however, fully alive to the objections referred to by the Hon. Member, and are doing their best to remedy them by training competent native teachers

Mr. Robertson asked further, whether the lack of teachers competent to give instruction in Arabic was not the result of the policy of the British Control in Egypt, and whether down till some years ago such teachers were not available.
Sir E. Grey asked for notice of the question.
PILGRIMS AT SUEZ
The following is a further answer to a questionre theSanitaryimprovementsatSuez:—
Foreign Office, March 27th. 1907.
Sir —

With reference to the question asked in the House of Commons by you on the 7th instant, I am directed by Secretary Sir E. Grey to state, for your information, that important sanitary and other improvements in the arrangements at Suez for the Moslem pilgrims on their way to and from Mecca are now being carried out on the lines suggested by the Director of the Suez Hospital in his report for 1904-5, page 81.
His Majesty's Agent and Consul-General at Cairo reports that it is expected that all will be finished by the 1st of August next.
I am, Sir, your most obedient, humble servant, (signed) E. Gorst.
Dr. V.H. Rutherford, M.P., 55, Wimpole Street, W.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, In a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits — free discussion.
THE GRANDM0ULIN AFFAIR
A LESSON FROM INDIA.

Sir,—I was surprised to see in yesterday's issue of the "Egyptian Gazette" that it was not improbable that no action would he taken by M. Grandmoulin against the newspaper , which alluded to his accidental shooting of the boy in the terms "guilty, as he is of assassination " It was hinted in the paragraph in question that as M. Grandmoulin was an official, the Egyptian Governement was adverse to his bringing an action for libel and that in consequence the Nationalists were congratulating themselves that these feeble tactics were a proof that the Government is afraid of the Nationalist party. If this vacillation on the part of the Government is really the case, Mustapha Pasha Kamel has indeed reason to declare that he has gained a signal victory and that, however false his accusation may be, when a European official of the Egyptian Government is concerned, he will be immune from legal consequences. Why cannot the Egyptian Government follow the example of the Indian authorities in deal-ing with such cases? Here is an example of how to deal with fanatical journalists, from the "Daily Telegraph" : —

"As to deliberate murders—unpremeditated, of course—of Indians by irate, irascible officers, instances, though rare, are not wanting. Only the other day two European officers of a district not very far from Lahore went out shooting on horseback with a mountod orderly. Amongst the other denizens of the forest which fell to their joint shots was a boar, a full grown, fat porker which the pair of worthies laid much store by to furnish them with the pièces de resistance of two or three heavenly feasts. As soon as the animal was despatched they asked their mounted orderly to carry the carcase secured to his saddle, The man, who was a follower of the Prophet, however, instead of complying with the orders of the huzoors, refused point-blank to do their bidding, or even to touch the unclean animal. For a second they stood aghast, petrified at his temerity, but for a second only. The next moment the sahib recovered his wits, and saw it was insubordination, or even worse, downright mutiny ! And what is the reward of mutiny Î Short shrift and a swing into eternity.

"No sooner thought of than this brilliant idea of the Imperial hunter was put into practice. He aimed at the poor Indian (who cared more for the faith that was in him, indeed, than even the favour of his official chief) and shot him dead, without compunction or remorse. If anybody was ever guilty of murder that identical sahib surely was. The British Indian Penal Code might perhaps call it culpable homicide not amounting to murder, but it was nothing but murder in cold blood. That murderer is at large to-day, enjoying the privileges of the dominant race and the sweets of life like any innocent man, and yet we have reason to believe the matter had soon reached the ears of higher authorities. The only thing done in the case, however, was to get the gentler man transferred from the district and a new man put in his place, with strict injunctions not to allow the skeleton in the official cupboard to see the light of day, and Up to now it has not seen the light of day."

So said the Punjabi, a Lahore native paper, a few months ago. The actual facts, as brought out in court, are as follows : Seven years ago— not "the other day"—a district superintendent of police, named Spencer, rode out to the house of a Mr. Donald, near Wazirabad, to join him in an afternoon's shooting. .Mr. Spencer rode a horse belonging to a native deputy-inspector. The owner of the horse was rather afraid of it and Mr. Spencer wanted to prove that beyond being restive it was quite harmless. Mr. Donald asked Mr. Spencer to stay to dinner, and when he agreed to do so he sent the horse hack to Wazirabad in charge of a constable named Rafat Ali. Afterwards Messrs. Donald and Spencer went out with their guns, but saw no game, and did not fire a single shot. Next morning it transpired that that the horse had arrived at Wazirabad without Rafat Ali, and on the following day the latter's body was discovered forty yards from the Grand Trunk Road. His injuries plainly showed that he had fallen from the horse on the back of his head, and been dragged for some distance with his foot in the stirrup. There was no mark of any bullet or shot wound. Two or three weeks later the widow of Rafat Ali petitioned for a pension, on the ground that her husband died on duty. Within three months a further petition was sent in, alleging that he had been shot, but no mention was made of the suppositious pig. There was an official inquiry, and the allegation was quickly disproved.

For his share in publishing the murder story the proprietor of the Punjabi, who was also printer and publisher, was sentenced to two years' rigorous imprisonment(since reduced to six months') and a fine of 1,000 rupees, and, in default of payment of the fine, a further term of six months' rigorous imprisonment and a fine of 200 rupees, and, in default of payment of the fine, a further term of three montlis' imprisonment.
Here is a worthy precedent for Egypt to follow.—Truly yours
ANGLO-EGYPTIAN.
Cairo, 9th April.

div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.
